div.p: The STRANGERS AT HOME; A Comic Opera, In Three Acts: As performed at the Theatre Royal in Drury Lane.
LONDON: Printed for Harrison & Co. No.18. Paternoster Row. MDCCLXXXVI.

div.head: TO HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS THE PRINCE OF WALES.
div.p:
IT being peculiarly the buſineſs of a dramatic writer, to ſelect thoſe popular topics upon which he is aſſured of having the public voice with him, it might naturally be expected that, after receiving Your ROYAL HIGHNESS's gracious permiſſion to lay this Dramatic Eſſay at Your feet, I ſhould eagerly have availed myſelf of the opportunity thus given me, of expatiating on thoſe manners, talents, and virtues, which conſtitute ſo general a theme of admiration. But minds truly
conſcious of meriting praiſe are ever reſerved and delicate in accepting it: and perhaps Your ROYAL HIGHNESS will not ſuffer a ſincere acknowledgment of merit, becauſe the panegyric of Princes has been too often ſtained with adulation.

Reſtrained by this conſideration, I muſt content myſelf with offering my humble acknowledgments for the honour conferred on me, in the countenance of my feeble endeavours to cultivate an elegant art which ſo eminently boaſts the protection of Your ROYAL HIGHNESS.

closer.signed: I am, with the moſt profound reſpect, Your ROYAL HIGHNESS's Moſt obedient, And moſt devoted ſervant, JAMES COBB.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE Author of the STRANGERS AT HOME would think himſelf guilty of great injuſtice, if at a moment when the Piece is ſo highly honoured by the public approbation, he ſhould forget how much of that approbation he owes to the abilities of the Performers, all of whom ſo kindly intereſted themſelves in its ſucceſs. To Mr. KING he has peculiar obligations, for the care and attention with which he ſuperintended the rehearſals of the Opera; and to that Gentleman's judicious criticiſms he is likewiſe highly indebted. Although it might be ſuperfluous for the Author to add his praiſes to thoſe which the public have ſo liberally and deſervedly beſtowed on Mr. LINLEY's Muſic, he cannot but congratulate himſelf on having had the aſſiſtance of ſo able a Maſter.

body.head: THE Strangers at Home. A COMIC OPERA.

div.stage: VIOLA and ALICE in a Balcony belonging to REGNALTO's Houſe.
A Proceſſion of Captives redeemed from Slavery croſs the Stage; among them are REGNALTO and LAURENCE.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: WELCOME once more our native land!
Where ſmiling Freedom's bounteous hand
Life's fading picture bids to glow
With tints ſhe can alone beſtow!
'Tis Liberty inſpires the lay,
To hail our ſecond natal day:
Hail, Goddeſs bright! by all ador'd;
By thee to more than life reſtor'd.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: What a glorious proceſſion, Ma'am!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Glorious indeed, Alice! to ſee ſo many of our countrymen redeemed from foreign ſlavery, and all by the munificence of the young and noble Octavio!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! I fancy this ſame Signor Octavio has enſlaved you at the very moment when he was giving others their liberty.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Oh, that my long loſt brother were but among theſe ranſom'd captives!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: And oh! that my long loſt huſband were among them too! Lord, Ma'am! talk of a brother—I'm ſure, when I was of your age, I ſhould have thought one huſband worth twenty brothers.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Hark!—I hear the muſic again!—Let us liſten.

div.stage: Some of the Crowd come forward with Flaſks of Wine; they appear to congratulate the Captives, who drink with them, and join in the following Catch.

lg.head: CATCH.
lg.l: Come, come, drink away, boys! let our glaſſes keep time
To the tune of the bells that ſo merrily chime!
Ding, dong; ding, dong, bell—that ſo merrily chime!
From ſlavery freed, we'll forget all our pains;
At the tyrant we'll laugh while he rattles his chains!
We'll laugh at his chains!
Thus muſic and drinking all ſorrow ſhall drown:
Then, my boys! let us take off our glaſſes;
Huzza! huzza! ev'ry bumper ſhall crown.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Viola!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: There is that croaking old raven, your guardian.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Viola, my dear! where are you?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Don't anſwer him, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Look, Alice! there are two men whoſe eyes ſeem rivetted upon us.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Where?—Eh!—Why, ſure—Yes—No—Yes, it is my poor huſband! It is Laurence!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Alice! why, Alice!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Coming, Sir, preſently.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Yes, there is Alice, ſure enough! My rib, my ſpouſe! and as plump as ever. She has not pined much after me, I ſee.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: It is my ſiſter! my Viola.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Viola!—Alice!—where are you?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Coming, Sir!—Plague take the old curmudgeon! You muſt go to him, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: She looks on me, but does not know me.
sp.stage: [Exeunt VIOLA and ALICE from the Balcony.
sp.p: And ſee! they vaniſh like ſpirits at the dawn of day.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Spirits! I am ſure, then, they are choice ſpirits. Heaven bleſs you, Sir, they are fleſh and blood, I'll warrant; at leaſt, I can anſwer for Alice.—But I think I ſcent the ſupper! Oh, for a fat capon, and a bottle of good wine!—I'll knock at the door.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: By no means: you know my ſuſpicions of Aldobrand, with whom I left the charge of my ſiſter, and my houſe. I am reſolved to remain concealed till I can ſatisfy thoſe ſuſpicions.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: But may'nt I ſatisfy my hunger, in the mean while, Sir?

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Have a little patience.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! patience is a bad phyſician; he has worn me to a ſkeleton already. If I don't change my doctor, he'll ſoon make a dreadful change in me! But here comes the Algerine captain who brought us over.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Noble Ibrahim! I thank Heaven that I am at length arrived where I may be enabled properly to acknowledge that benevolence whoſe rays illumined our night of ſlavery. Nay, ſtart not! are you ſurprized to find gratitude among the Chriſtian virtues?

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: No, my generous friend; wide as the ſun darts his beams, he finds that precious jewel, which decks alike the Turban and the Croſs!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Then let me expreſs the grateful ſentiments I feel—

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: It will be ſufficient that you ſuffer me to remain unknown and unnoticed in this city.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: We muſt haſten to offer our reſpects to the generous Octavio.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I had much rather offer my reſpects to a well-covered table: we ſhall be in better ſpirits after ſupper; my gratitude will grow ſtronger as my ſtomach gets fuller.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Away! no trifling. We muſt pay our compliments where they are due.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p:
Well, Sir, if it muſt be ſo, I'll follow you preſently: though mine, I fear, will be but empty compliments.—Ha! here comes
our fellow-captive, Firelock, the Engliſh ſoldier; that merry old fellow, whoſe jeſts and ſongs made us ſo often forget our ſorrows.
Once more welcome to European ground, my old ſon of fun and frolic!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Aye, my boy! and a ſon who has never diſhonour'd his family. 'Tis only your common dull metal that ruſts with the breath of care and misfortune: the high poliſh of mirth and good-humour always caſt off the envenomed damp.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: And did you really never meet with any misfortune which obliged you to complain?

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Faith, I never remember lamenting but two misfortunes in my whole life: one, that I was not at the Pruſſian review; and the other, that I had not the honour of being among the brave fellows beſieged in Gibraltar.—But that's all over now! However, I hope I ſhall yet live to fight for my country.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I am going to return thanks to Signor Octavio.

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: So ſhall I, as ſoon as I am dreſt.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Dreſt!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Aye, I hardly dare call myſelf an Engliſhman while I wear the badges of ſlavery. Our noble captain, Ibrahim, has kindly preſented me with the very cloaths in which I was taken by the Algerines: ſo, within an hour, you ſhall ſee me in that character which commands reſpect in every part of the world—a Britiſh ſoldier!—and then I ſhall want nothing but a miſtreſs to make me compleatly happy.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: They, you know, are to be purchaſed every where.

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Aye, but I would as ſoon think of buying a friend as a miſtreſs. Always barter love for love, and friendſhip for friendſhip: for, egad! when either of the commodities are put up to ſale, depend upon it they are not worth buying. However, I don't deſpair of making myſelf pretty well underſtood by ſome kind Florentine girl or other. Love, I take it, is an univerſal language; much the ſame in moſt countries.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: But, you will remember, it is a language in which the oldeſt ſcholars are not generally the greateſt proficients!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: I underſtand you, young man! But I fear nothing. I am a mixture of ſpring and autumn: old Time and I have had ſo long a battle, that he has given up the point at laſt, and left me maſter of the field. Beſides, if even a miſtreſs ſhould be coy, I have yet my bottle to comfort me.

lg.l: "In vain whining lovers their Cupid ſhall prize,
"And boaſt that his godſhip's deriv'd from the ſkies;
"Tho' divine was the birth of the young god of Love,
"Our Bacchus, we know, was the ſon of great Jove:
"Let us number Love's vot'ries, I think we can prove,
"That tho' all the world drink, 'tis not all the world love."
When malicious young Cupid o'erwhelms us with grief,
In the comforts of Bacchus we find ſure relief:
Tho' Chloe, diſdainful, deny you her charms,
When glowing with rapture you ruſh to her arms;
Pay your court to a bumper, and there you will find
A gay ſmiling miſtreſs eternally kind.
Nay, when chilling age, like bleak winter, comes on,
And the ſunſhine of beauty and love ſhall be gone;
Still conſtant your bumper will ſmile to the end,
And ſupply both the places of miſtreſs and friend.
Let us number Love's vot'ries, I think we can prove,
That tho' all the world drink, 'tis not all the world love.

head.hi: SCENE, a Room in REGNALTO's Houſe.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: There are all the people in Florence out at their windows, gaping at this ſcurvy proceſſion of ſlaves. Tinkle but an old braſs ſhovel in the ſtreets of this city, and the inhabitants will ſwarm like bees at the ſound! One would think there was a triumph for ſome victory, to-day.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: And what can be a nobler triumph, than the triumph of humanity! what a nobler victory, than that of freedom over ſlavery!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Pſha! don't tell me! Self-preſervation is the firſt tie of nature.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: But is it the only tie, Sir?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Charity ſhould begin at home.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: And ſhould charity end at home, too?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Certainly! you would not have me turn Charity out of doors? She keeps houſe with ſober decent people, and only goes aſtray with ſuch ſpendthrifts as Octavio.—By the bye, Viola, Octavio has invited us to his houſe to-day.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: To his houſe, Sir! [Aſide— How my heart beats!] And do you mean that we ſhould accept of his invitation?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Why, yes! for once in a way.—We are to meet Signor Lucilio and his wife Laura there. [Aſide.— Laura is a charming creature!]

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed, Sir!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed! I'll take care to watch Octavio: for I ſuppoſe he'll teaze you with a parcel of ſtuff, that he is dying for love of you, and—

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Do you really think he will?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Oh, yes! theſe rakiſh young dogs begin to make love the moment they ſee a woman, juſt as naturally as you would ſay 'Pretty Pol!' to a parrot: but you muſt not anſwer him.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Perhaps, then, he'll think that my ſilence gives conſent.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Frown at him, as you do at me when I make love to you, and I'll be hang'd if he miſtakes your ſilence for conſent then!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Well, Signor Aldobrand, ſince you teach me the leſſon of diſſimulation, you muſt e'en take the conſequences.

lg.l: Since you teach me, dear Sir, the art of deceiving,
You ſurely can ne'er take it ill,
If, while with attention your leſſons receiving,
On yourſelf I ſhould practiſe my ſkill.
And when of your own wit the dupe I have made you,
All doubts of your art 'twill remove;
For you can't but eſteem it a compliment paid you,
To ſhew you how much I improve.
So doating parents oft have ſmil'd
At miſchief from a fav'rite child;
And view'd, with fond, exulting joy,
The growing genius of the boy;
Who gives poor Hodge's aukward bow,
And ſhews you how he goes to plough;
Hits off the Vicar's vacant ſtare,
Wry faces makes behind his chair;
"Then ſlily mocks the Parſon's quaffing,
"While they almoſt expire with laughing.
"Soon panting for ſatiric fame,
"Our little maſter ſeeks new game;
"And, tir'd of laughing at the gueſt,
"On hoſt and hoſteſs breaks his jeſt:
"The father's gouty ſteps takes off,
"His purblind eyes, and winter's cough;
"Nor can Mamma's pert, ſmiling leer,
"Eſcape the wicked urchin's ſneer;
"While giggling ſervants raptur'd ſit,
"To ſee how well the little wit"
Now apes the ſimpers of Mamma,
Then coughs and hobbles like Papa.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Fabio! this prodigal fool, Octavio, has ranſom'd another parcel of ſlaves from Algiers.

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: Yes; the proceſſion has diſturb'd the whole city.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: And this is called generoſity! For my part, Fabio, I think ſuch doings ſhould not be tolerated. When Fate has thought fit to ſend a man into ſlavery, I think it is flying in the face of Fate to releaſe him from his ſituation.

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: Your reaſoning is very juſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Fabio! I never hear of a releaſed captive, but I think of Regnalto. If by any ill luck he ſhould find his way back to Florence—

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: Impoſſible, Sir! You know, I have aſſured you—

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Why, yes, you have aſſured me: but you muſt know, friend Fabio I don't think that telling truth is your forte!—However, run and view this new cargo of ſlaves. Bring me but a true account of Regnalto's not being among them, and I'll compound with you for a month's lying afterwards.
Well, Alice, any news of the worthy Regnalto?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Alas! no, Sir.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Ah!—Nor of your huſband?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: No, Sir. I have heard nothing of poor Laurence. [Aſide— The old wretch ſhan't diſcover that I have ſeen him.]

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: My poor friend! I muſt give a tear to humanity.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir. [Aſide.— It coſts you nothing, or elſe you would not give that.]

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Now to our own concerns!—Do you know, Alice, I have reſolved to take Viola with me to viſit Octavio?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: To viſit Laura, you mean! I find ſhe is to be of the party.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—Why I don't think Laura has been inſenſible to my amorous glances!—Only I have never yet had an opportunity of explaining myſelf.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: [Aſide.— An old fool!—I'll turn this to Viola's account.] Lord, Sir, what a Turk you are among the women! Marrying a young girl of eighteen, and ſeducing a married woman of twenty, at the ſame time! I declare, I ſhould not expect it from you!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Pſha! pſha! the older a man grows, the better uſe he ſhould make of his time.—But tell me, Alice, how can I contrive to get a private interview with Laura?—Suppoſe in ſome diſguiſe? Let me tell you, diſguiſe is very uſeful to us men of gallantry.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p:
No bad thought, Sir!—What ſay you to the dreſs of a
Monk? It will not be the firſt time that garb has covered deſigns as pious as yours.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: A Monk's habit!—Zounds! a man might as well make love in his ſhrowd! 'Tis a monument erected to ſignify the deceaſe of human frailty.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir! It will only, like other monuments, point out where the remains are depoſited.—But, Sir, you know, a little money will be neceſſary for this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Money!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir! Generoſity is the only teſt of a lover's being in earneſt.

lg.l: A fig for all your whining ſtuff,
Fine ſpeeches ſweet as honey;
Of love you can't give proof enough,
Except you give your money:
Were I your miſtreſs, faith and troth,
Your av'rice ſoon would loſe me!
For compliments are but mere froth—
You muſt, good Sir, excuſe me!
Of all the arrows Love can boaſt,
The golden ones are beſt, Sir;
And he who boldly bids the moſt
Can never be in jeſt, Sir.
'Tis true that I make rather free;
But, faith! you ſhan't refuſe me:
So draw your purſe-ſtrings now, d'ye ſee—
Or elſe you muſt excuſe me.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: But, egad! I run a great hazard here.—Indeed, it is true, I have no other means to get at Laura, than by riſquing Viola in Octavio's houſe: but then I muſt depend on your watchful care over her, Alice!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Truſt to me, Sir.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: If the young ſlut ſhould dare to liſten to him—If ſhe ſhould forget herſelf ſo far, as to—

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Follow her own inclinations, as you do, her crime would certainly be of the blackeſt dye.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Pſha! But you know the weakneſs and inexperience of young girls.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: For which reaſon their faults are to be more ſeverely puniſhed! Well, I admire the men! who, while they are continually boaſting a ſuperiority of underſtanding, very modeſtly reſerve to themſelves the privilege of committing acts of folly with impunity.

head.hi: SCENE, An Apartment in OCTAVIO's Houſe.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Lord, Sir! we have waited a great while to ſee Signor Octavio. I dare ſay he will excuſe our going now. Ceremony, I am told, is quite out of faſhion with great folks.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: What, would you quit his houſe without thanking him for your liberty? Do you not feel the warmth of gratitude for ſo ineſtimable a gift?

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Grief, thy tyrant reign is o'er,
Now I tread my native ſhore!
Mirth, fair Freedom's ſiſter gueſt,
Shall impart her choiceſt zeſt
To each flaſk of gen'rous wine
Gaily offer'd at her ſhrine:
See the ſparkling glaſs goes round;
Care, avaunt! tis hallow'd ground!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I think humility ſhould teach us, that to wait among the ſervants is the propereſt ſituation for us.—I hear them now at ſupper, Sir; and, as we are but ſlaves—

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Slaves! the noble Octavio will receive us as friends.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Then, Sir, for that very reaſon we ſhould go to ſupper!—When a generous man entertains his friends at his own houſe, he is always beſt pleaſed to ſee them eat heartily.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Peace! Here comes Octavio.
Generous Octavio! we owe you thanks which language can never expreſs.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Silence, Sir, will be the moſt acceptable eloquence on that ſubject. Your mien and deportment beſpeak you of no vulgar rank.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE,
sp.p: He ſays nothing of my mien and deportment.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Do not miſtake me; I have not the ſmalleſt wiſh to know any thing you may deſire to conceal. No one is under reſtraint here: as long as it ſuits your convenience, make this your home; and accept, in the mean time, whatever my houſe affords.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Thank you, my lord! I wiſh we had known as much before; perhaps we ſhould have made free: I am ſure I ſhould. But to night we ſup at Signor Regnalto's; though, I think, a little ſnack before ſupper—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO,
sp.p: What! were you acquainted with Regnalto?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Yes, my lord; and he had a very great regard for him, too, or I am much miſtaken.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Perhaps, then, you know his ſiſter?

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! I fear ſhe has forgotten me. It is ten years ago ſince I held the little prattler on my knee.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: And now, I ſuppoſe, Signor Octavio would be glad, in turn, to hold the little prattler on his knee.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Alas! had Viola a parent living, there would be no longer any obſtacle to our happineſs: but, to have my hopes blaſted thus, by an avaricious guardian!—

lg.l: When Prudence oppoſes the dictates of Love,
A parent may fairly our choice diſapprove:
'Tis kind, then, to ſave us,
From what would enſlave us;
To tell us the tale of Experience with truth,
And check by advice the wild ſallies of youth!
But when Prudence ſmiles on the ſoft nuptial band,
And Affection and Reaſon are join'd hand in hand;
With Hymen's torch lighted,
Our mutual faith plighted;
Alas! how ſevere is Fate's partial decree,
That cruelly tears me, my charmer, from thee!

sp.p: Sir, I will confer on you what, to the noble mind, is one of the moſt acceptable favours—an opportunity of ſhewing your gratitude. I love Signora Viola: here is a letter, in which I propoſe that ſhe ſhould fly with me this evening, from the power of the wretch with whom her unſuſpecting brother too haſtily entruſted her. This letter you ſhall do me the favour to deliver.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE,
sp.p: A mighty pretty employ my maſter has got into!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: I have invited Aldobrand to bring the charming Viola with him to-day: but as I hardly expect any ſucceſs from that ſcheme, this letter is my laſt reſource.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: The captain of the ſhip from Algiers, Sir, begs to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Adieu! I will not offend your zeal to ſerve me, by urging that ſecreſy on which my ſucceſs depends.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Laurence!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: This is rather a ſingular ſituation!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Not at all, Sir! Nothing can be more regular. When a lover thinks of marrying his miſtreſs, her neareſt relation ſhould always be one of the firſt perſons conſulted on the buſineſs.—But here comes my dear Alice!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Don't diſcover who I am, Laurence.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I wont, Sir; I won't!—How her eyes ſparkle while ſhe is looking for me!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Enquire after my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I will, Sir.—Pretty rogue!—Pretty rogue!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: I am very impatient—

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; ſo am I!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Ah! my poor Laurence!— (Embracing him.)

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Poor indeed, Alice!—I—I—Well! and how d'ye do? I had a thouſand things to ſay to you: but they are all jumbled together; and, like a great crowd trying to get out of the playhouſe, they preſs on one another till they quite choak up the paſſage.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: You are waſted away prodigiouſly!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Aye! I am not the man I was, Alice.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: I am very ſorry for it, Laurence!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: When you and I parted, I was as plump as good living and laughing could make me; but now I may, indeed, ſay—my wife is my better half!
And pray, how does your young lady do?—Pretty little ſoul! ſhe—

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you!—But I ſee we are not alone. Who is that?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: A brother captive of mine. He is both deaf and dumb, ſo you may ſay what you will before him.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: The rogue has not loſt his old knack at invention.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: La! what a pity it is, that ſuch a well-looking man ſhould have any deficiencies!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: But tell me, how is your young lady?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: As well as any poor girl can be, when ſhe is doom'd to marry a miſerly old guardian; who tells her, forſooth, that ſhe ſhall find a father in him.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: An old villain!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Well, Alice, and do you think there ſo any thing ſo much amiſs in a huſband's becoming a father!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Signor Regnalto, he ſays, has certainly died in ſlavery.—Now I think of it, can you tell me any news of our old maſter?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I can't indeed, Alice; ſo don't aſk me any thing about him.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Poor man! Gone, I ſuppoſe! I am ſorry for him.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: We ſhall never have ſuch another maſter!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: No, never! He was the moſt good temper'd creature! One of the beſt men in the world for a ſervant to live with. So eaſily cheated!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Eaſily cheated! No, no, Alice! That's too much.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Nay, Laurence, I am ſure you know it as well as any body living. How many bottles of his beſt wine did you drink, and made him believe the rats got into the cellar and eat away the corks?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Lord! Lord!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: I ſhall make ſome intereſting diſcoveries.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Not another word, Alice!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Why, what the deuce are you afraid of? You may be ſure a dumb man can't make any words about the matter.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: 'Tis lucky for you, ſirrah, that you have deprived me of my ſpeech!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Hey-day!—What, can he whiſper?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: No; but he makes a queer comical kind of a noiſe; which I, who am uſed to him, can underſtand as well as if he ſpoke ever ſo diſtinctly.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: And what does he mean?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Why, to let me know he is hungry, as I am: and, i'faith, 'tis no wonder, conſidering how long it is ſince we taſted roaſt-meat! Let us take him home with us, Alice. You will find him a mighty agreeable companion; he will never contradict you!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: I declare, he ſeems as if he underſtood every word we ſay!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Oh, he is very intelligent; I can teach him any thing.—But come! Never did ſoldier long more for conqueſt than I do to attack my ſupper.—My dear Alice, we'll be as merry as love and good wine can make us.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Heavens! Montano, what a difference muſt this Algerine habit make in you! when even I did not diſcover you, who but three years ago was the moſt intimate friend you had in Florence.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: But Laura!—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Inconſolable for your loſs, ſhe ſequeſter'd herſelf from the world for ſome time.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: That was kind!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: At length, however, to the ſurprize of every one, after ſlighting the firſt noblemen in Florence, ſhe ſuddenly married a young ſtranger.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: A ſtranger!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Named Lucilio. Gentle, yet lively in his manners; in his perſon, an Adonis in miniature.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Do not oppreſs me with his praiſes; rather ſay that he is baſe! unworthy!—that my ſword—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Hold, Montano! I conjure you, by our friendſhip!—Lucilio and Laura are here. Conſider, this houſe is their ſanctuary: retire but for a moment, you ſhall ſee Laura preſently; nay, you ſhall even ſpeak to her.—I beg only a moment's delay.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Oh, Roſa! this uncertainty of my Montano's fate, like the torturing arts of medicine, protracts my unhappy life but too long!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Upon my word, Madam, you muſt think me a very complaiſant huſband, thus to make me the confidante of your affection for another!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: You are a ſtrange girl! However, I muſt own, it was a lucky thought for me, which ſuggeſted this ſcheme of calling you my huſband, to get rid of the importunities of my lovers.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Yes, really! and lucky for me, too; from your humble companion in petticoats, to become your lord and maſter in breeches.—I am ſure I may truly ſay, marriage has made a man of me!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: But hear me, Roſa!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Roſa!—you forget that I am your huſband! Aye, and ſo kind! and ſo indulgent, too! Am not I the beſt of huſbands? [LAURA ſighs.] Ah! you will never know my value, till you have got your beloved Signor Montano; and then you'll ſoon find the difference between us!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: You trifler!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: However, though we may forget ourſelves in private, let us at leaſt take care to behave like huſband and wife in public; that is no more than many married couples oblige themſelves to do. But, ſeriouſly, my dear Madam, is it poſſible you can doubt Montano's conſtancy? Duty and reaſon will ſecure—

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Duty and reaſon, when oppoſed to love!—Oh, Roſa!

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: In vain, when with the fatal dart,
(Unerring in his aim)
The little Archer wounds the heart,
Does Reaſon urge her claim:
The pow'rful ſun of Beauty's eyes
Beams forth too bright a ray;
She thaws cold Duty with her ſighs,
And Reaſon melts away!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO,
sp.p: My friend Ibrahim is lately from Algiers, Madam.
sp.stage: [Introduces MONTANO, then walks apart with ROSA.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: I—I—had a friend carried to that part of the world, Sir, for whom I am much intereſted.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: [Aſide— How guilt fluſhes her cheeks!] I knew him well, Madam.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: You knew him—a—his name was—

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: Zounds! I forgot to wait for my name.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Montano; a native of Florence.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Montano!—He—he—was my friend, Madam.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Then you can tell me news of him! [Aſide— Now for life or death!]

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: He is no longer conſidered as a Chriſtian ſlave. He has taken the turban. I myſelf ſaw him laſt in the Algerine habit.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Heaven and earth!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: I have heard him often repeat the name of Laura.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Indeed!—You diſtreſs me, Sir!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Montano lov'd her once; lov'd her, as the ſlave who now adores her!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: You are bold, Sir!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: And is that, Madam, a fault, in the eſtimation of a lady?

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: I have a huſband, Sir, who will anſwer whether it ought not to be ſo in mine!—Signor Octavio, a word with you.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: And do you, Sir, take upon you to chaſtiſe every one who dares to love that lady?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Not I, upon my ſoul, Sir! It would be a very troubleſome office. Beſides, it is too flattering to my vanity, to have my wife univerſally beloved—

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: She was beloved by Montano! Did you know him, Sir?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Montano! Montano!—Oh! the man who went one afternoon to fiſh in the Mediterranean, and was himſelf caught by an Algerine rover!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Did you know Montano, young Sir?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Oh! yes, Sir! I recollect he had the vanity to be my rival. Poor man! I ought not to abuſe him; for I owe him infinite obligations, for the merriment Laura and I have ſo often had at his expence!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! Sir, you dare not repeat what you ſay!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Really, Sir, I don't deſire it. Tautology in converſation is very diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: If Montano were here—

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Why, if he were, Sir, I ſhould certainly pity the poor devil! To be laugh'd at by a ſucceſsful rival would be intolerable; and, really, I could not help it!—Ha! ha! ha!

lg.l: When firſt I began, Sir, to ogle the ladies,
And prattle ſoft nothings, as a pretty fellow's trade is;
While with rapturous praiſes I dwelt on each feature,
If I ſtole a ſly kiſs, 'twas—'Fye, you wicked creature!'
But ſoon, in tones lower, and ſofter, and ſweeter,
Half-pleas'd, they would whiſper—'Fye, fye, you wicked 'creature!'
Indeed, my attractions no gallantry needed,
Each evening ſtill conqueſts to conqueſts ſucceeded:
Perplex'd how ſo many fond claims I ſhould parry,
To ſettle all diſputes, I reſolv'd, faith, to marry!
Then preſs'd lovely Laura, in language ſtill ſweeter,
Till, bluſhing, ſhe whiſper'd—'I'm yours, you wicked creature!'

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Hark'e, Signor Lucilio; I will not hear Montano inſulted with impunity! I ſhall walk by the river-ſide, two miles from the city, at ſix to-morrow morning! You underſtand me, Sir?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: [Aſide— A pretty ſcrape I am got into!]—Perfectly, Sir! You find the air from the water beneficial to your health.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Inſulting coward! draw inſtantly!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: [Looking round, and perceiving OCTAVIO approach to part them.] Zounds, Sir! with all my heart. This is not to be borne!—Signor Octavio, nothing but the reſpect I bear you, prevents my puniſhing that boaſter as he deſerves! Your preſence protects him from my rage! [Aſide to LAURA— Let us be gone; I am frightened out of my wits!]

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Signor Lucilio, I am concerned for my friend's warmth!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: As to that, Sir, I am very happy you interfered. I declare, I tremble to think what might have been the conſequence!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Signor Octavio, what has paſſed will, I am ſure, plead my apology for begging your permiſſion to retire.

lg.l: Good Signor, you'll excuſe me!—
Pray don't, my dear, refuſe me!
Lucilio, let us go.
Laura, you muſt excuſe me!—
Satisfaction you ſhan't refuſe me,
Before I go.
Good Signor, you'll excuſe me!
Pray don't, my friend, refuſe me.—
Hold, Sir, you muſt excuſe me!—
Pray, good Lucilio, go!
Be by your reaſon aided!
Why won't you be perſuaded?
Hear me!
Come, your paſſion ſmother!
For this you'll thank me, ſome day or other.
Lucilio, let us go.—
Signor Octavio, with thanks to you, Sir,
Adieu, adieu, Sir!—
Lucilio, let us go.
No, I'll not be perſuaded!—
Hear me!—
Eh! well, then, my paſſion I'll try to ſmother.
Adieu, Signor! I go.—
But I ſhall find, Sir, ſome time or other,
For a private word, or ſo.
Why won't you be perſuaded?
Hear me!
Hold! Before a lady,
Your anger ſmother • —
Pray, good Lucilio, go:
You may, you know, find ſome time or other,
For a private word, or ſo.
No, Sir, I ſhan't excuſe you!
Juſtice I won't refuſe you,
Before you go!—
No, I'll not be perſuaded!—
Hear me!—
My anger I cannot ſmother!—
Nay, Sir, you ſhall not go!
Well, I ſhall find, Sir, ſome time or other,
For a private word, or ſo.

div.stage: Enter ALICE, and LAURENCE with a Bottle of Wine in one Hand and Bread in the other.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: TELL the cook to make haſte, Alice. I like my victuals rather under done.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: You have been us'd to eat your meat rare, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Yes, the meat that came to my ſhare in Algiers was very rare, indeed!—not above once a month.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: And how did they treat you, Laurence? Tell me all about it.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: They treated me with my board, to be ſure—to ſleep on, I mean; a ſcarcity of bread and water; and plenty of ſtripes and hard labour. For my part, I had rather pay my own way in Florence, than be treated ſo by the beſt Algerine of 'em all!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Pray, Laurence, had your maſter many wives?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Wives! aye, in every hole and corner of his houſe: they ran about like rabbits in a warren!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: And did not you turn poacher now and then, and ſnap up a ſtray rabbit?—Eh! Laurence?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Not I, indeed! I had a much keener appetite for a fat capon.—Hunger is a bitter enemy to gallantry!—Beſides, the Infidels have ways of keeping their wives to themſelves, which we have not yet attain'd.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: By making ſlaves of them!—Thank my ſtars, that odious faſhion does not prevail in Chriſtendom!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: "No, the matter is juſt revers'd with us: in all Chriſtian countries, the wives keep their huſbands in ſubjection."—But here comes Madam Viola!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Honeſt Laurence, I am rejoic'd to ſee you once more at home!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Thank ye, Ma'am!—I am much rejoiced to ſee myſelf here!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: I imagine you have had a ſufficient ſample of travelling?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Enough to laſt me my life, Ma'am!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: And what think you of the men and manners where you have been?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
VIOLA.
sp.p: Laurence, you are releaſed from the chains of a tyrant, juſt time enough to ſee me in fetters!

lg.l: Woman's fate is ſtill diſtreſſing,
Be her lot whate'er it will;
Man perverts her every bleſſing
To a cauſe of future ill.
If with charms her form enduing,
Nature kindeſt care employs,
Man, the gaudy prize purſuing,
Conquers firſt, and then deſtroys.
Riches ſerve but to entoil her;
Like the bee with honey ſtor'd,
Her wealth allures the cruel ſpoiler,
And dooms her—victim of her hoard.

sp.p: "To-morrow is the day fix'd by my inexorable guardian to make me his wretched wife.—Oh, for the preſence of a brother, to ſave me from this living death!"
But Alice tells me you can give no tidings of the unfortunate Regnalto?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I know no more of him than this good man!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: And who is he?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: He can't tell you that himſelf; he is dumb.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: The poor fellow is juſt return'd from ſlavery, Madam!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Perhaps he may have ſeen my brother: I'll queſtion him. How complacently he ſmiles upon me! I hope I ſhall be able to underſtand him.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Well, Ma'am, my wine is out; ſo we'll leave you with our ſilent friend, while we go and toaſt you in bumpers from a freſh bottle!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Poor ſlave! perhaps he has a ſiſter in ſome foreign land, who, like me, mourns the abſence of a brother! [Taking a Picture from her Pocket.] Here is Regnalto's picture!—Precious image of a beloved brother, let me preſs thee to my heart!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: "How ſhall I ſupport myſelf in this trying ſcene!"

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p:
If he has ever ſeen Regnalto, he will remember the likeneſs.
[Shews it to him; he looks at it attentively, and ſhakes his Head.] Alas! he knows not the reſemblance.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: I had almoſt forgot my errand!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: What would you with me, gentle ſlave? [REGNALTO offers her the Letter from OCTAVIO, and makes Signs of Secreſy.] A letter! [Opening it haſtily.] And from Octavio! [Reading.] 'Deareſt Viola! our ſituation muſt plead my excuſe for the propoſal I thus abruptly offer. To-morrow is to make you the wife of Aldobrand; ſuffer me to ſnatch you from the miſery in which this deteſted marriage would involve us. Do not doubt my honour: warm as my paſſion is for the charming Viola, I can never forget the reſpect due to the ſiſter of Regnalto—

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: Noble youth!

sp.speaker: Viola,
sp.p: —'On a word depends your fate and mine. I ſhall be with ſome choſen friends, at the balcony which looks into the garden, a little before midnight. Let me hope that happy hour will conſign you to the care of the impatient Octavio!'—What am I to do! [REGNALTO pleads for OCTAVIO in dumb Shew.] He endeavours to perſuade me; he pleads for his benefactor.—Will you accompany me?— [REGNALTO puts his Knee to the Ground, and kiſſes her Hand.] Then I will meet Octavio! [She kiſſes the Letter, and intimates that ſhe agrees to the Propoſal.
My guardian here!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Hey-day! whom have we here? A lover in diſguiſe! This is your gallant-elect, I ſee, Madam; and he is kiſſing hands on his appointment!—Who the devil are you?

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: He is now my ſervant.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: That is to ſay, you are his miſtreſs. So I ſuſpected!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: How you miſunderſtand things! He is—

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: I aſk him, and not you, what he is!—I ſuppoſe he can ſpeak for himſelf?

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Indeed he can't, Sir.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Not ſpeak for himſelf! A pretty kind of a lover, then, he muſt be!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: A lover! The poor creature is juſt come from Algiers; and I have employ'd him as my ſervant, from motives of compaſſion.—I tell you, he can't ſpeak.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: But I ſuppoſe he can eat and drink; and that comes very expenſive!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: And is this the way you think to gain my regard, by thwarting me in every thing I propoſe?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Nay, nay! my dear wife, that is to be! I'm ſure I'll do all I can to make you happy. I agree, then, to take this ſpeechleſs gentleman into our ſervice.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: I thank you, Signor.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Thanks! And is that all I am to receive from your lips, Viola?—I muſt! indeed, I muſt!— [Offering to kiſs her.]—Well, I ſhall make you pay for all to-morrow! Thoſe roſy lips will be mine when we are married, Viola!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: When we are married, they ſhall be yours; but, till then, good Signor, they muſt remain my own!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Well, Fabio, what news?

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: Why, Sir, on this occaſion, we may really ſay, no news is good news: for I can hear nothing of Regnalto. You may depend upon it, he is not in Florence.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: I am heartily glad of it, good Fabio! and will double the reward I promis'd you.
sp.stage: [ALDOBRAND and FABIO ſit down at a Table.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: Fortune has thrown an excellent opportunity in my way, to diſcover the villainy of this falſe friend, in whoſe honour I have ſo unwarily confided.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Hey, Roberto! get wine and glaſſe: and, d'ye hear! ſhew Dummy the way to the cellar. We muſt try to make ſomething of him!— [Exeunt ROBERTO and REGNALTO.]—Come, Fabio! let's ſit down and enjoy ourſelves! You have put me in charming ſpirits; and we'll have a bottle of my beſt wine on the ſtrength of your good news!
Well, Roberto, does he appear to be a handy fellow?

sp.speaker: ROBERTO.
sp.p: O, yes, Sir! [REGNALTO enters.] he ſeems to know the ways about the houſe as well as if he had been us'd to it!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Aye, aye! we muſt converſe with him by ſigns: I dare ſay he'll ſoon be able to find us out.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: I hope ſo!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Roberto, you need not ſtay: let him wait on us.
A dumb waiter is ſometimes very convenient!

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you retain not only your ſpirits, but your wit!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: My dear Fabio, the news you bring of Regnalto gives me new life! Let him but keep out of my ſight, and my bottle in it—and then, Time and Care, I defy you!

lg.l: The ills of life in vain aſſail,
I never yet would yield me;
Nor ſhall their malice e'er prevail,
While frolic Mirth can ſhield me:
Like curs they ſnarl, but dare not bite;
I heed them not at all, Sir!
But laugh at all their harmleſs ſpite,
And ſtill ſing—Tol de rol lol, Sir.
I ever ſcorn'd, with face of woe,
Proud dames to dangle after;
But bent with ſmiles young Cupid's bow,
And tipt his ſhafts with laughter:
Succeſs ſtill crown'd each merry dart,
Black, fair, brown, ſhort, or tall, Sir;
I vanquiſh'd ev'ry female heart,
With—Tol de rol lol, de rol, Sir.
"Let firſt-rate ſingers ſtretch their throats,
"In fine falſetto ſqueaking;
"With new and ſtrange unnatural notes,
"Applauſe from faſhion ſeeking:
"The blockhead Connoiſſeurs among
"E'en let them trill and ſquall, Sir;
"Give me, my boy! a jolly ſong,
"That ends with—Tol de rol lol, Sir."
In ſpite of Dons ſo grave and wiſe,
Till o'er old Styx I ferry,
I always will moſt highly prize
Whatever's blithe and merry.
May Love and Laughter ever be
Attendant on my call, Sir!
Here's what I've always lov'd, d'ye ſee—
A glaſs to—Tol de rol lol, Sir!

sp.p: Where do you think Regnalto is now, Fabio?

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: At a pretty good diſtance from us, I'll anſwer for it. You know I bargain'd with a Turkiſh merchant to buy him at Algiers, and tranſport him from thence to Conſtantinople!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: So you told me!

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: After which, he was to be convey'd to Arabia, and ſold to a chief of the wild Arabs.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: A pretty journey theſe good people have mark'd out for me!

sp.speaker: "FABIO.
sp.p: "And, I dare ſay, by this time, he is as expert at robbing a caravan as the beſt freebooter among them.

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "Then he has travell'd to ſome end, Fabio.

sp.speaker: "FABIO.
sp.p: "Yes, Sir! and I hope that will be the end of his travels.

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "With all my heart! Give Dummy a bumper to that toaſt—"May Regnalto end his travels where he is now!
sp.stage: ["They drink, and give REGNALTO a Glaſs of Wine.

sp.speaker: "FABIO.
sp.p: "Well done, honeſt Dummy! Egad! he empties his glaſs to that toaſt!

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "He little thinks that he is drinking to the captivity of his old acquaintance; for I dare ſay Regnalto and he have had the baſtinado together many a time in Algiers."

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Signor Lucilio, Sir.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Lucilio! What the devil can he want with me? I hope he has not diſcovered my deſigns on his wife!—Shew him up.—Fabio, let Dummy retire with you for the preſent.
Signor Lucilio, ten thouſand thanks for this honour! Believe me, I am heartily glad to ſee you!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: I am come, Signor Aldobrand, to requeſt your advice and aſſiſtance in a matter of great moment to me.

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "I am ſure I ſhall be particularly happy—

sp.speaker: "ROSA.
sp.p: "I know you are a man of gallantry—

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: "Egad! I am ſorry for that.

sp.speaker: "ROSA.
sp.p: "And therefore I wiſh for your counſel.—But, are we out of hearing?

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "As ſnug as a conclave of cardinals!"

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Give me leave to aſk you, what meaſures do you think I ought to purſue with the man who has dar'd to make love to my wife?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: A—a— [Aſide— Oh! that I were but ſafe out of the room!] Why, ſurely—is it poſſible that—

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Poſſible! why not, Sir? Is not Laura handſome enough to be an object of temptation?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I think ſo, Sir! Don't miſtake me. [Aſide— What ſhall I ſay to him?]

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: When I conſider the nature of the affront!—

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: But conſider, at the ſame time, good Signor, how liable we all are to frailty! Temptation is an enemy who wreſtles with us through life, growing ſtronger as we grow weaker; and if youth can't reſiſt him, 'tis not to be wondered at that he ſhould eaſily trip up an old man's heels!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd to puniſh him ſeverely!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: [Aſide— I ſhall be expos'd to all Florence!] Are there no apologies which you could be prevailed on to receive?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: What apologies can he offer, after having had the aſſurance to threaten my life!—

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: I threaten his life!—What the devil does he mean now?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: The preſumption to challenge me to ſingle combat!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Challenge you!—Upon my veracity, I never dreamt of ſuch a thing!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Yes, the haughty Algerine dared me to meaſure ſwords with him!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: The haughty Algerine!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Ibrahim, the commander of the veſſel laſt from Algiers!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: [Aſide— I am reſtor'd to life!] Give me your hand, my dear Signor Lucilio! We'll have the ſcoundrel hang'd, drawn, quarter'd, flay'd, and carbonaded!—A dog! a raſcal! a villain!—a—ſuch an abominable attempt!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: But how ſhall we manage, my dear friend? I have every thing to dread from him while he is at liberty. You are a magiſtrate, and can aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: He ſhall be thrown into priſon in two hours time!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Will that be ſtrictly legal?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Legal! aye, to be ſure, if it can ſerve a friend. Laws were made for the benefit of ſociety; and are not our friends the very flower of ſociety?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: But let us be careful not to infringe the ſtrict letter of the law.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Aye, that is a true oracle; always doubtful in it's meaning. We lawyers are the prieſts, and who ſo proper to expound it as we who make it? The letter of the law reminds me of a fanciful cloud in a ſummer ſky; though no two perſons can agree in what it really repreſents, you may look at it till you make what you will of it.

sp.speaker: "ROSA.
sp.p: "And yet how beautiful are thoſe clouds when gilded by the ſun of equity!

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "Pſha! pſha! when the clouds gather faſt, the ſun of equity, as you call it, ſometimes finds it a deviliſh hard taſk to ſhine through them." But come, let us to buſineſs; we have not a moment to loſe. I'll diſpatch the officers of juſtice after this Ibrahim, and they'll ſeize him the inſtant they ſet eyes on him!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Well, Signor Aldobrand, I perceive you improve on the poets, who repreſent Juſtice as blind: you kindly remove the band from her eyes, that ſhe may diſtinguiſh objects clearly.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Modern Juſtice is only blind to the faults of her friends.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: And what does ſhe do with her ſword?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Reſerves that for their enemies.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Then her ſcales only remain to be diſpos'd of!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Which are too uſeful to be parted with. They are for the receipt of fees; one ſcale for the plaintiff, and the other for the defendant: of courſe, you know, that which is beſt fill'd makes the other kick the beam!—And ſo much for juſtice.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Well, Alice, then the charming Viola is permitted by her guardian to viſit this houſe to-day? You may depend on my gratitude!

sp.speaker: "ALICE.
sp.p: "I will, Sir; though I own it is not a quality on which, generally ſpeaking, I place the greateſt dependance.

sp.speaker: "OCTAVIO.
sp.p: "Surely you do not doubt it's exiſtence: you do not think it a mere phantom."

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, my experience has taught me, that gratitude is ſomething like a ghoſt; every body talks of it, but nobody ſees it appear!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: As to that, I can eaſily conjure up the apparition!— [Giving her a Purſe.] How do you like it?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Oh! I admire your ſpirit, I aſſure you, Sir! It could not appear in a prettier ſhape.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: But tell me, dear Alice! how am I to elude the vigilance of Aldobrand?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Very eaſily, Sir. You muſt know the old fool expects to meet Laura her, with whom he is moſt deſperately in love!—But I ſee him coming: I'll engage him, while you ſlip down ſtairs, and entertain your miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Here I am! ſo amorous—but ſo frighten'd! My heart is like a volcano in Iceland; fire and froſt at the ſame time. If Laura ſhould not requite my paſſion—if I ſhould fail, Alice!—

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Fail, Sir! there is no ſuch word in the lover's dictionary.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Then I ſuppoſe mine is the old edition; for, egad! I think I ſee it in the title-page, in black letter. It frightens me ſo, that I can't turn over a new leaf!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I'll comfort you with an example, in a ballad which I learnt of an Engliſh captain who us'd to viſit my poor maſter, Signor Regnalto.

lg.l: Young Roger the ploughman, who wanted a mate,
Went along with his daddy a courting to Kate;
With noſegay ſo large, in his holiday cloaths,
(His hands in his pockets) away Roger goes.
Now he was as baſhful as baſhful could be;
And Kitty, poor girl, was as baſhful as he:
So he bow'd, and he ſtar'd, and he let his hat fall;
Then he grinn'd, ſcratch'd his head, and ſaid—nothing at all.
If aukward the ſwain, no leſs aukward the maid;
She ſimper'd and bluſh'd, with her apron-ſtring play'd:
Till the old folks, impatient to have the thing done,
Agreed that young Roger and Kate ſhould be one.
In ſilence the young ones both nodded aſſent:
Their hands being join'd, to be married they went;
Where they anſwer'd the parſon with voices ſo ſmall,
You'd have ſworn that they both had ſaid—nothing at all.
But mark what a change! In the courſe of a week,
Kate quite left off bluſhing, Hodge boldly could ſpeak;
Could joke with his deary, laugh loud at the jeſt:
She could coax, too, and fondle, as well as the beſt.
And, aſham'd of paſt folly, they've often declar'd,
To encourage young folks, who at courtſhip are ſcar'd,
If at firſt to your aid ſome aſſurance you call,
When once you are us'd to it, 'tis—nothing at all.

sp.p: A lover is like a ſwimmer: fear will be ſure to ſink him.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Then, egad! I ſhall certainly go to the bottom, Alice!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Never fear that, Sir!—Truſt to the cork-jacket I have brought you.— [Shewing his Diſguiſe]—This will keep your head above water, I'll warrant.—Come, Sir, let me help you on with it.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Heigho! make haſte, and lead me to Laura, that I may face the enemy, while I have courage enough left for the attack.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: I'll go and reconnoitre, Sir.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: And, d'ye hear? keep an eye on Viola!—You know Octavio is a few years younger than I am; and young girls have a deviliſh hankering after green fruit!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Who have we here? a Friar! I did not expect to meet with ſo holy a man. I was in ſearch of one Signor Aldobrand, a rich old lawyer of this city.—Do you know him, father?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: I know the man!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Perhaps you are his confeſſor? I'faith! if you are, you muſt have a troubleſome taſk of it, by all accounts: I am ſure you deſerve to be paid well for keeping ſuch a batter'd old conſcience in repair!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: How I long to break the raſcal's head!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: But I can't think where the old fellow can be gone! He was ſeen to enter this room not half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Why, what the devil! are you ſet to watch him, you dog?

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Hey-day! here's language for a man of mortification! You ſeem to have forgot yourſelf, father.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Rather ſo, indeed!—But, if you knew me better, you would find me a true ſon of the church.

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Aye, I dare ſay! One of thoſe dutiful children who are ſeldom better pleas'd than when they are drinking their mother-church in full bumpers; and, leſt her family ſhould be extinct, like good ſons, take all the care in their power to provide her with grandſons.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: I forgive your ſcurrility, friend!—You ſhall find, that Monkiſh manners can cover liberality of ſentiment.

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: As an extinguiſher covers a candle!—But here come Octavio and Viola.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: A comfortable ſituation I ſhall be in, to be ſure! for, though I ſhould be cuckolded before my face, I muſt, like a ſnail, draw my horns within my ſhell!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: We are all ſafe, Sir! the enemy has retreated, and left you maſter of the field.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Follow Aldobrand, my faithful friend, leſt he ſhould return unexpectedly.—But who is this?

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Oh! as for this ghoſtly father, though he may hitherto have been a neutral power, I dare ſay, he is a true politician; and, now victory has declared for you, will have no objection to become your ally.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: A lucky thought! This good prieſt ſhall join our hands.—You tremble, Viola?

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Oh, Octavio! you will forgive that timidity which makes me ſtart at the precipitancy of a meaſure—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Which alone can releaſe you from the power of an avaricious tyrant!—I'll ſubmit the caſe to this worthy man; convinc'd that I could not have fix'd on any perſon better qualified to decide the matter.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: I wiſh to my ſoul the worthy man were ſafe at home!—A plague on this maſquerading! If he finds me out, I ſhall have his ſword through me in a twinkling!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: My good father, this lady is threatened with marriage by her guardian; a wretch whom, if you knew, you muſt deſpiſe!—She has bleſs'd me with the avowal of her affection!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: That avowal, Octavio, I willingly repeat. Why ſhould I bluſh to own my acquaintance with Love, while he is the companion of Virtue?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: The devil take her fine ſentiments!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Thus, then, let me ſeize this charming hand! and our good friend, here, I am perſuaded, will chearfully aſſiſt me in making it my own. [ALDOBRAND ſhakes his Head.] "What, you ſay 'No!' Perhaps you are not aware what a ſad old fellow this guardian is: he reviles eccleſiaſtical government whereever he goes; and declares he hates a prieſt ſo much, that he is ready to faint at the ſight of his habit. He ſays it reſembles charity, for it is always ſure to cover a multitude of ſins."

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: You ſeem to be miſtaken in the perſon to whom you apply, Octavio?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Moſt curſedly miſtaken, if he knew all!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: As to his ſhaking his head, that is a diſorder eaſily cur'd by a proper application to the palm of the patient's hand!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Egad! if I refuſe money, he'll ſoon diſcover me to be no churchman.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Are you better, father?—Not quite cur'd yet, eh!—I muſt touch the other hand, then.— [Giving him more Money.]—Now, I'll anſwer for it, he'll find himſelf perfectly well!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Then I'll e'en get off while I am well!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO,
sp.p: Not ſo faſt, my good friend!

div.stage: Enter ALICE; who ſtarts back with ſeeming Surprize, and then whiſpers VIOLA.

sp.speaker: VIOLA,
sp.p: My guardian, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: ALICE,
sp.p: Bleſs me, what do I ſee—To what a paſs of wickedneſs is this world arrived!—Oh, my poor maſter! how he has been impoſed upon! And now, perhaps, he'll think me an accomplice in the plot. I ſhall run mad with vexation!—As for you, Signora Viola, I ſhall take care that you ſhall never ſpeak another word to that vile ſeducer! [Aſide to VIOLA— Tell him immediately how we are circumſtanced.]— [Aſide to ALDOBRAND, while VIOLA whiſpers OCTAVIO—Ah! my dear Sir, how lucky it was for us all that I came in juſt at the moment I did!—What deceit there is in the world!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: A d—n'd deal, indeed!—Alice, you muſt take care they don't ſuſpect me.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: [Aſide to ALDOBRAND— Leave that to me, Sir.] I bluſh for you, Signora Viola, to behave ſo to your guardian!—And as for you, Signor Octavio—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: I ſhould have been married by this time, had it not been for that piece of mock ſanctity, "who dar'd to receive money for what he never intended to perform." But I'm reſolv'd to take the moſt ſignal revenge!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Dear Sir! what do you mean? [Aſide to OCTAVIO— Stick to that.] Bleſs me, how your eyes roll! Don't be raſh!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: What is to become of me, Alice?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Surely, Signor Octavio, you don't mean to attempt his life?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Hold your tongue! He won't think of killing me, if you don't put him in mind of it!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: To be ſure, the poor gentleman is entirely in your power. It would be the eaſieſt thing in the world to deſtroy him without it's being diſcover'd. You might hang him in the garden, or drown him in the river—or ſhoot him——or—let me ſee!—

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: The devil's in the wench!—You forget that you are counſel for the defendant!

sp.speaker: ALICE,
sp.p: It may happen to the beſt advocate, who has no retaining fee to remind him: that is the only anchor which can keep him ſteady to you.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Why, I gave you one this morning! But you ſeem ſoon blown from your anchor, as you call it.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Conſider, Sir, what a ſtorm we are in!—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: It is impoſſible, my dear Viola! Not even your entreaties can diſarm my reſentment!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: What, Sir! not if he agrees to marry you?

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO,
sp.p: Agrees to marry me!—What the devil can ſhe mean now?—On that condition, indeed!—

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Leave me to calm the fears of the good man!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Well, father, I leave you to your female friend. Eloquence, you know, is the gift of the ſex: I dare ſay, Alice will perſuade, you to liſten to the voice of reaſon, though I cannot.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p:
Egad! if Reaſon ſpeaks through your voice, I don't wonder that ſo few people in the world liſten to her; for the very tone
of it is enough to throw one into a quaking fit!—A pretty ſort of an engagement you have form'd for me, Alice! How the devil am I to fulfil it?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you muſt e'en run away: that's the moſt approved remedy, when a man can't fulfil his engagements!

div.stage: Enter MONTANO; who, ſeeing ALDOBRAND and ALICE, retires to the Back of the Scene.

sp.speaker: "MONTANO,
sp.p: "A confeſſion ſcene, as I take it: I may chance to profit by it."

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: But then I leave Viola behind me!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: I'll take care ſhe ſhall ſoon follow you. I can perſuade Octavio to any thing. You ſee I have gain'd his confidence!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Egad! if you have gain'd his confidence, you have made a pretty comfortable addition to your own ſtock; for I think he has as good a ſhare as any man I ever knew!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: I have news to tell you of your beloved Laura!—

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: His beloved Laura!

sp.speaker: "ALICE.
sp.p: "But I fancy, in this jumble of paſſions, love has ſunk to the bottom.

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "Why, i'faith, fear is the oil of the paſſions: attempt to mix it with whatever you will, it is always ſure to ſwim at top.

sp.speaker: "ALICE.
sp.p: "Which proves that, with you, love is weighty, and fear light. But I have to inform you, Sir, that Laura left this houſe on pretence of illneſs, and that ſhe is now at home, where ſhe expects you."

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: I'm on the rack!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Why, I—I—ſhould like to viſit her!—But are you ſure ſhan't meet with another couple who want to be married?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: My dear Signor Aldobrand, conſider what an opportunity! I have ſettled every thing with Laura's maid: ſhe will admit you as a friar ſent to viſit her miſtreſs by her confeſſor, who is indiſpoſed.

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: Diſtraction!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: To perſonate a confeſſor!—Excellent!—I—I will go, Alice!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Then I will ſtep into the garden, to ſecure Octavio and Viola in chat. You follow me preſently.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, a father confeſſor, who has the keeping of a pretty girl's conſcience, leads a mighty agreeable life! The pleaſure of giving abſolution muſt be ſo great, that, like a ſkilful phyſician who delights in being conſtantly employed, one might be tempted now and then to make a flaw in a patient's conſtitution, for the ſatisfaction of performing the cure!

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: Stop, doctor!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Ah, good Signor! what would you have? Do you wiſh to be married!—Spare my life, and command my ſervices!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Signor Aldobrand, I have overheard the whole of your pious converſation; and am ſo much edified by it, that I am reſolv'd to quit the turban, and aſſume the religious habit which you wear!—Yes, I am determined to try the virtues of that magic garment, which can blind the eyes of a fine woman to age and infirmity; for, ſurely, without ſuch aſſiſtance, you could never have preſumed to think of gallantry!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: I don't know that!

sp.speaker: "MONTANO.
sp.p: "Can that ſhrivell'd countenance, and thoſe tottering limbs, be form'd for ſeduction?

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND."
sp.p: There is no fix'd ſtandard for beauty: and ladies often differ in their taſtes!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: We'll ſettle that point another time. In the mean while, we muſt exchange dreſſes; you ſhall have my veſt and turban, in return for your diſguiſe of holineſs!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Turn Mahometan!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Men of true piety, like you, never regard externals. Come, uncaſe, my old Adonis! No more words to the bargain.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, 'tis a deviliſh hard bargain!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Now, then, Diſſimulation aſſiſt me to avenge the cauſe of an injur'd lover, and puniſh the loſt and guilty Laura!—Signor Aldobrand, one ſerious word before we part!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: One ſerious word!—Why then, perhaps, you have hitherto been in jeſt?

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Dare not, as you regard your life, to follow me; nor to diſcover whither I am going! And ſo, adieu!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Good bye to ye!—Heigho! a pretty metamorphoſis! [Looking at himſelf.] I am made a mere peg, to hang caſt-off cloaths on! A child's doll, dreſs'd and undreſs'd ten times in a day! I ſuppoſe I ſhall keep my Algerine dreſs no longer than till ſomebody elſe takes a fancy to it!—Oh, here comes one of the footmen! I may as well begin to ſtrip, for I dare ſay I muſt put on his livery.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Signor Montano, my maſter begs you will conceal yourſelf immediately. The officers of juſtice are in queſt of you. He ſuſpects foul play, as they are ſent hither by Aldobrand, who was ſeen here juſt now diſguiſed as a Friar.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: So! I have iſſued a warrant to apprehend myſelf!

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Hark! the officers are forcing their way in; and my maſter and his followers are defending the entrance with their ſwords!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis all over with me! Here am I, in my rival's houſe, with another man's cloaths on my back; having loſt my character, my wife, my miſtreſs, and almoſt loſt myſelf! I am an actual numeration-table of loſſes; they riſe upon me by tens, hundreds, and thouſands.—And here come more plagues! How the devil ſhall I manage to conceal myſelf! Egad, I'll ſlip down this ſtair-caſe!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Caſt away your ſcruples, my love! and rely upon me.

lg.l: By that eloquent language which ſpeaks in the eyes;
By the ardour which breathes in the lover's ſad ſighs,
As in abſence the nameleſs ſoft wiſhes ariſe;
I pr'ythee now hear me, my deareſt!
By thoſe fond, anxious doubts, which all lovers muſt feel,
Which, altho' ſome few moments of bliſs they may ſteal,
Yet fan love's pure flame, and ſtill wound but to heal;
I pr'ythee now hear me, my deareſt!
By our hopes, when the moment of meeting is nigh;
When affection no longer can pardon deny;
Hopes which live in a look, in a word, in a ſigh;
I pr'ythee now hear me, my deareſt!
By my paſſion, for which words, alas! are too weak;
By that love-dawning bluſh which now glows on your cheek,
And ſo kindly avows what your tongue will not ſpeak;
I pr'ythee now hear me, my deareſt!

sp.p: Make yourſelf perfectly eaſy, my dear Viola! Montano will protect you. I thought he was here: but I know the agonies of his mind drive him from ſociety, to ſeek relief in ſolitude.
Alice! where is the Algerine captain?

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Algerine captain!—Oh, you mean the man with the turban, whom I met juſt now ſtealing down the dark private ſtair-caſe which leads to the garden, with his hands before his face, like a ſulky child endeavouring to eſcape a whipping! There is no fear of your loſing him, Sir, except he can creep through the key-hole; for I lock'd the door as I came up, and put the key in my pocket, to prevent old Aldobrand's ſurprizing us.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: The door is faſt, ſure enough!—I muſt try t'other ſide, as ſoon as the coaſt is clear!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: That gentleman whom you met in the Algerine dreſs is a native of this city; "and unfortunately attach'd to Signora Laura.

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: "The devil! then I am diſcover'd!"

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: His name is Montano.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: That's very well, i'faith!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: I have the ſtrongeſt reliance on his friendſhip.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: He little thinks that my appearance of friendſhip is like ſome other friendſhips—a mere diſguiſe, which I ſhall throw off as ſoon as convenient.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: In a word, I will entruſt Viola to his care, while I ſtay to face the expected ſtorm.

sp.speaker: "ALICE.
sp.p: "Shall I run and fetch him, Sir?

sp.speaker: "OCTAVIO.
sp.p: "It is by no means neceſſary: at this unfortunate moment, my converſation would ſerve only to diſtreſs him.

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: "It would, indeed, moſt plaguily!

sp.speaker: "OCTAVIO.
sp.p: "Only beg him to accompany Viola to my houſe by the river-ſide. Two truſty ſervants will attend him.

sp.speaker: "VIOLA.
sp.p: "Surely, Octavio, I ſhould be ſafer under this roof?

sp.speaker: "OCTAVIO.
sp.p: "No, my charmer! Montano will conduct you to a more agreeable aſylum; to a place which, I hope, my Viola will ſhortly call her home.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: "Yes, egad! I'll take care ſhe ſhall ſoon find herſelf at home!

sp.speaker: "OCTAVIO.
sp.p: "Oh, Montano! I commit my exiſtence into your hands!"—Tell him, my dear Alice, to watch over her as if ſhe were the darling of his own ſoul. I know he will with pleaſure receive the precious pledge from me.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: With great pleaſure, indeed! "And, I fancy, when once I get the precious pledge in my poſſeſſion, you will find it no eaſy matter to redeem it.—But I muſt retreat to my hiding-place."

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: We have no time to loſe, my love! Give your hand to my friend, and your guardian!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND,
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: But conſider, your friend is unknown to me. I never even ſaw him.—Oh, Octavio! I have a thouſand fears!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Diſpel them all, my love! Our conſtancy will render us invulnerable to the attacks of fortune.

lg.head: TRIO.
lg.l: Abſence, all ills denouncing,
A fond adieu pronouncing,
We part—all joy renouncing
Until we meet again.
Yet, while theſe ills enduring,
See Hope, with ſmiles alluring,
(Bleſt ſmiles! all ſorrow curing)
Still points to Hymen's chain.

lg.head: CATCH.
lg.l: How great is the pleaſure, how ſweet the delight,'
When Love's ſilken bands willing captives unite!
Well pleas'd in their bondage, his vot'ries remain,
And, proud of ſubjection, exult in his chain:
Oh, Love! how bliſsful's thy meed!
The pray'r of thy vot'ries is—ne'er to be freed.
'How great is the pleaſure, how ſweet the delight,'
When Love's ſilken bands willing captives unite!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: INDEED, Roſa, my mind is too ſeverely wounded by this dreadful news of Montano.

lg.l: Thou art gone away from me, my love!
Long ſhall I rue that luckleſs day,
When thou wert torn from me, my love.
Did but thy heart remain the ſame,
As when it left this ſhore, my love!
Alas! it owns another flame;
Of me thou think'ſt no more, my love.
With jealous pangs my boſom torn,
I wiſh that fair of thine, my love;
That fatal fair! may treat with ſcorn
Thoſe vows which once were mine, my love!
But, ah! how ſharp Love's venom'd ſteel;
Inconſtant tho' thou be, my love,
Ah! may'ſt thou never, never feel,
What Laura feels for thee, my love!

sp.p: I cannot muſter up ſpirits enough to execute your ſcheme.

sp.speaker: "ROSA.
sp.p: "But conſider, my dear Madam, it is the only means by which I can ſave myſelf from the fury of this mad Algerine."

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: How can you aſk me at this time, when my heart is ſo ſenſibly touch'd?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Well, Madam! and do not I run the riſque of having my heart ſenſibly touch'd by the point of a ſmall-ſword! Let me tell you, that is much the worſt touch of the two. I repeat to you, Madam, that old rogue Aldobrand has let Ibrahim eſcape; and, while he is at liberty, I dare not venture abroad.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: And ſo you would really wiſh me to receive this odious viſit from Aldobrand—

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: That I may ſurprize him with you, and work on the fears of the old wretch, to make him ſecure Ibrahim.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: I don't like your ſcheme, Roſa. There is an indelicacy in ſubjecting my ears to be offended with the mention of an illicit paſſion.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: There might be, I grant you, from the lips of a youthful gallant, like Ibrahim; "in whoſe breaſt the paſſion glows hotenough to ſcorch the reputation of every female who expoſes herſelf to it's influence:" but, as for poor old Aldobrand—Lord, Ma'am! in him it is the mere Aurora Borealis of love; a few ſtraggling faint rays from the ſun that is ſet, which vaniſh almoſt as ſoon as they are ſeen, and have only the appearance of heat without the reality!—To give me a fair occaſion for coming into the room, you muſt ſcream out; upon which I ruſh in, and—But who have we here?

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: My abrupt viſit will apologize for itſelf, Sir, when I tell you that I come to offer you my ſervices in aſſiſting to puniſh Aldobrand, who is now entering your houſe diſguis'd as a friar.

sp.speaker: LAURA,
sp.p: Heavens, Roſa! how could he have diſcover'd—

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Do not be ſurprized: I was inform'd of the whole affair by a very pretty girl at Signor Octavio's.

sp.speaker: ROSA,
sp.p: He means Alice.

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: The ſame, Sir! She order'd me to engage in your ſervice; and I would no more diſobey the commands of Beauty than the articles of war.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Perhaps you have expectations of reward from your fair employer?

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Why, look ye, Madam! Love and Honour have ever been my commanding officers; and I ſhould not deſerve the name of their ſoldier, if I wanted the inducement of reward to do my duty.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: You have been bred a ſoldier, I preſume?

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: No, Madam; I once had a pretty ſnug little eſtate, which my wife and my friends obligingly help'd me ſoon to get rid of: ſo, as I was too honeſt, or too proud, to live by the ſame means as many of my neighbours, I paid my debts, as far as I could, and took up a brown muſquet. The expectation of happier days has ſupported me through all my misfortunes, and the anticipation of ſocial mirth has ſmiled on me even in the hour of battle.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Fir'd with ardour to engage,
The ſoldier dares the battle's rage!
When groans, which ſhall be heard no more,
Echo to the cannon's roar;
When the flying ranks are broke,
And all is loſt in clouds of ſmoke;
Death ſtalks triumphant o'er the field,
On every ſide the vanquiſh'd yield,
And fainting victors ſcarcely live
Their dear-bought laurels to receive!
Still he bleſſes the hours when, baniſhing care,
He ſhall triumph again in the ſmiles of the fair;
When wine, wit, and mirth, ſhall Love's pleaſures increaſe,
And his laurels ſhall bloom with the olive of peace.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Here comes Aldobrand, I vow!—We muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Let me accompany you; for I muſt have a few moments to prepare myſelf for the meeting.

div.stage: Enter MONTANO in the Friar's Habit, with a SERVANT.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: If you'll ſit down a moment, my good father, I'll acquaint Signora Laura that you are here.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: To what a dilemma have my ill ſtars reduc'd me. My errand here is to tempt that virtue which I hope to find ſuperior to temptation. "I muſt engage in a conflict where I dread to obtain the victory. If ſhe reſiſts my importunities as Ibrahim, it will at leaſt afford me a ſatisfaction to find that, though falſe to love, ſhe is yet true to virtue." But ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Perhaps, Signor Aldobrand, you are not a little ſurpriz'd at my conſenting to this interview?—

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: 'Sdeath! then ſhe has really expected Aldobrand!

sp.speaker: "LAURA.
sp.p: "I can venture to aſſure you, however, that my motives for it are very different from what you may imagine. I hope you will not miſinterpret my conduct.

sp.speaker: "MONTANO,
sp.p: "No, it ſeems to ſpeak pretty plainly for itſelf!"

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: I rely entirely on your diſcretion.

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: So it appears.—Alas! ſhe don't ſeem to have made any uſe of her own, indeed!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: What can occaſion his ſilence? I am in a moſt aukward ſituation!—A—a—Sir, I underſtood that you had ſomething of a particular nature to communicate. [Aſide— I hope Roſa will be at hand to relieve me!]

sp.speaker: "MONTANO,
sp.p: "Perhaps ſhe apprehends an interruption from her huſband, and means that I ſhould faſten the door.

sp.speaker: "LAURA,
sp.p: "That is not at all neceſſary: you may—you may venture to declare your ſentiments to me freely.

sp.speaker: "MONTANO,
sp.p: "This is taking effectual care that I ſhan't miſinterpret her, indeed! I ſhall never be able to contain myſelf!"

sp.speaker: ROSA,
sp.p: I hear no ſcreaming yet: I fancy Laura has no reaſon to complain of the violence of the old gentleman's paſſions.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: You are ſtill ſilent, Signor Aldobrand! [Aſide— What the deuce can be the matter with the man?]— [MONTANO kiſſes her Hand.]—Hold, Sir! this freedom is too much! Can this be the wiſe, prudent, and diſcreet Aldobrand?

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: No, Madam! 'tis the fond, the faithful Ibrahim!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Ah! I am betray'd; and am fallen a victim to my own imprudence!
sp.stage: [Breaks from him, and exit. At the Moment ROSA enters on the oppoſite Side, MONTANO wraps himſelf up in his Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Your ſervant, good Signor Aldobrand! I have caught you at laſt. "Poſſibly you have aſſum'd this diſguiſe in order to give Laura ſome intelligence of Ibrahim?

sp.speaker: "MONTANO,
sp.p: "He little thinks that he is ſo near the truth.

sp.speaker: "ROSA.
sp.p: "Or very likely you have reſolved to make love in maſquerade, as it might not be quite convenient to appear in your own perſon?

sp.speaker: "MONTANO,
sp.p: "Right again! The man has an admirable knack at gueſſing!

sp.speaker: "ROSA.
sp.p: "You ſee I am not ignorant of the perſon whom that diſguiſe conceals, nor of the purpoſe for which it was aſſum'd.

sp.speaker: "MONTANO,
sp.p: "I'faith, I rather perceive you are ignorant of it, by your bullying in ſo high a ſtile."

sp.speaker: ROSA.
