sp.p: I find the Algerine is not yet taken: that rogue who was to be hang'd, drown'd, flay'd, and carbonaded! You have let him eſcape, after all your promiſes to impriſon him in ſpite of law or equity.

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: A pretty hair's-breadth eſcape I have had!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: But you have been bribed: I doubt not that you are intereſted in his being at liberty?

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: Rather ſo, indeed!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: And I am to be aſſaſſinated by him! I dare ſay, I am betrayed! and that, at this moment, he knows that you iſſued the order for apprehending him at my requeſt?

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: Not till this moment did he know it, good Signor Lucilio!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Not that I fear the arm of the haughty Moor, could I but meet him face to face. I only dread leſt, lurking under ſome diſguiſe, he may attack me at a moment when I am not prepar'd; for I fancy my courage was never yet brought in diſpute.

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: I dare believe not: there can be but one opinion of it!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: But not even the abject ſilence which guilt impoſes on your tongue ſhall ſave you from my juſt revenge!—I have a very curious piece of ſteel here!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: And I believe I have juſt ſuch another!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: And, here's a third, which I'll match with either of them!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Ibrahim!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: My friend, the Algerine captain, fighting in ambuſcade!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: The ſame.—But perhaps, Signor Lucilio, this is one of your unprepar'd moments?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: I—I—am not yet prepar'd for you, indeed, Sir!—You—you are ſafe.— [Putting up her Sword.]—Aldobrand muſt be the firſt victim of my vengeance!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Pitiful boy! draw inſtantly! Are theſe the evaſions—

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: I am not to be frighten'd, Sir!—I—I ſhall not fight at preſent! True courage, Sir, like mine—always calm—always calm, I ſay—and intrepid, looks down, Sir, with contempt, on the impotent attacks of—of—of malice—and—and, in ſhort, Sir—I—I ſhall find another time to ſee you!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: I am not ſorry he has eſcap'd you: ſuch a conqueſt would have diſgraced your ſword.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: And this is the being for whom Laura has quitted me! But I'll think no more of it!—Ere I quit Florence for ever, the villainy of this Aldobrand, in perverting the laws to his unworthy purpoſes, ſhall be puniſhed. He is a traitor to his country, who tamely beholds her laws and liberties invaded, either by the aſſaſſin hand of knavery, or the bolder attacks of tyranny.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Accurs'd the wretch, whoſe coward ſoul,
Aw'd by Oppreſſion's guilty hand,
Dares not the lawleſs power controul,
Which drives fair Freedom from the land;
Who, deaf to Honour's call ſublime,
Tamely to tyranny ſubmits,
Becomes th' accomplice in the crime,
And ſhares the treaſon he permits!

div.stage: MONTANO's Algerine Habit and Turban lying on a Chair.

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Alas, how ſuddenly have I been awaken'd from my dream of bliſs! How unexpected the reverſe! But a moment ago, I ſeem'd to be treading the paths of happineſs, and whither have they led me! Yet does not Hope deſert me: I will careſs the kind gueſt; and, like a drowning wretch, ſtill continue to claſp him while I ſeem to be irrecoverably ſinking!

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Thus we view the treach'rous morning
With falſe ſmiles the hills adorning;
Tho' of ſtorms they give no warning,
Yet no ſooner ſeen than gone:
Still, while clouds on clouds impelling,
The ſtorm drives on, with ruin ſwelling,
Fancy, every cloud diſpelling,
Paints to-morrow's happy dawn.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Once more I bid you welcome home, my young Madam!—Why, you made but a ſhort viſit to your lover!—Egad! ne and I have been playing the Engliſh game of cricket with you: I bowl you at him, he bats you back again to me; you come plump into my hands, ſo he is caught out, and there is an end of the game!—Go to your chamber, and ſtudy the charms of retirement.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I am quite impatient to hear your ſucceſs with Laura?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: [Aſide— Ah, the cockatrice!—But I'll diſſemble.]—Don't mention her, Alice: I have had enough of gallantry; the very name is poiſon to my ears—a piſtol to my head—a dagger to my breaſt!—

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: Signora Laura is below.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Indeed!—Why—why—there is great condeſcenſion in her viſiting me.—I'll wait on her!

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: What, Sir! would you put the ſteel to your breaſt?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Ah, Alice! if it be ſteel, it is certainly touched with a loadſtone; for I am irreſiſtibly drawn to it, though I dread it's point.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Poor Viola! thus to be awakened in a fright from her dream of happineſs!—But I'll aſſiſt her to fit the old dotard, yet!—
sp.stage: Enter MONTANO in the Friar's Habit.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Signor Aldobrand! can I believe my eyes? Why, I parted with you but this moment, and now I ſee you in the very dreſs—

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: Which was intended as Aldobrand's paſſport to Laura!—I have done with it, my dear, and am come for my own cloaths!
sp.stage: [Throws aſide the Friar's Dreſs, and puts on the Turban, &c.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Are not you the Algerine captain who behaved ſo kindly to the poor ſlaves?—I am ſure you muſt be a good Chriſtian in your heart!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Alice, give orders that my doors be inſtantly ſhut againſt that ruffian Ibrahim!—Here is poor Lucilio come to claim my protection: he and Laura are afraid to truſt themſelves in their own houſe.—That fellow is born to be the plague of my life; wherever I go, I am ſure to meet him!

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: I underſtand that you have iſſued an order to apprehend me, good Signor?

sp.speaker: ALICE,
sp.p: I hope the captain will give him a ſound beating!—I'll go and keep the ſervants out of hearing.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p:
I mean to ſurrender myſelf to Juſtice, if neceſſary; but I fear, though you call yourſelf her repreſentative, you do not ſpeak the
voice of your conſtituent; but are like a bad inn, which promiſes good accommodation on its ſign, while there is nothing but extortion within!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: How dare you thus affront a magiſtrate?

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Miſcreant! do not rouze my anger! or, by all your villanies, I ſwear—

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Help! help!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: But I beg pardon! your life is that gentleman's property; he has ſworn to diſpatch you before he fights me.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: I'll give up my turn, with all my ſoul!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Signor Aldobrand, pay no attention to the idle dreams of a madman.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Well, if you will have them dreams, I dreamt that, under this diſguiſe— [Taking up the Friar's Dreſs.]—I believe we are all three acquainted with it—under this diſguiſe, I ſay, the ſeducing, gallant Aldobrand, meant to attempt the chaſtity of that gentleman's wife—

sp.speaker: ROSA,
sp.p: How, Signor Aldobrand!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: And that the brave and noble Lucilio, conniving at the deſigns of this youthful raviſher, lay in wait for him, to take advantage of his cowardice.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: How, Signor Lucilio!—And who the devil told you all this?

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: There is my author; who, alſo, while I was diſguis'd as a friar, informed me of your kind intention, not only to impriſon, but to hang, drown, flay, and carbonade me!—I think thoſe were your words, Signor Aldobrand?—I make no ceremony, gentlemen, in acquainting you with each other's raſcality! I am perſuaded you are both too much of the poltroon, for me to apprehend any bloodſhed between you.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Very pretty, upon my ſoul!—They ſeem to be excellent company, ſo I'll e'en leave them together.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I ſhall remember this!—But I muſt keep down my paſſion.

lg.l: Good Sir, in vain you bend your brow,
And look ſo queer, I know not how,
And ſet your arms a-kimbo:
My laughter you provoke;
Ha! ha! ha! ha!
So pleaſant is the joke.
If, Sir, I choſe to try my ſkill,
Of fencing ſoon you'd have your fill;
But, mighty Signor Whiſkers,
With you I won't engage:
Ha! ha! ha! ha!
A fig for all your rage!
Nay, pr'ythee, friend, don't draw your ſword;
I ſhan't draw mine, upon my word!
Nor could I fight for laughing,
Were I to look at you:
Ha! ha! ha! ha!
And ſo, ſweet Sir, adieu!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: My friend, my Montano! how happy your preſence makes me!—Then my Viola is ſafe!—My viſit here, at this time, will prevent Aldobrand's ſuſpecting the ſcheme by which he is depriv'd of his prey—

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: He muſt mean my perſonating Aldobrand at Laura's! How could it have reach'd his ears?

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Tell me, Montano, how did ſhe look? what did ſhe ſay? Relate every circumſtance?

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Why, when I firſt entered the houſe, ſhe took me for Aldobrand.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Took you for Aldobrand!—Ha! ha! ha! A ridiculous miſtake! and no great compliment to you, neither!—Well, did ſhe not often call upon Octavio?

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: No, ſhe never mention'd your name.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: That's ſtrange!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Her tongue faltering with conſcious guilt—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Conſcious guilt! What a ſtrange phraſe for the amiable timidity of the ſex!—But proceed.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Juſt as I caught her in my arms—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Her huſband ruſh'd into the room, and ſurpriz'd us.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Her huſband!—What huſband?—I talk to you of my Viola; the lovely charge whom I entruſted to you not two hours ago.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Viola entruſted to me!—Why, my dear friend, either you or I muſt have loſt our wits, for I don't recollect that I ever ſaw the lady in my life.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: I am in torment!—Oh, Viola!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: She is now in the houſe: Alice, by your own orders, gave her into the hands of Aldobrand; who, by ſome unaccountable accident, was dreſs'd like Ibrahim.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Rather whimſical in you to miſtake Aldobrand for me; and no great compliment to me neither, as you ſay! [To OCTAVIO.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: It is not too late to retrieve every thing.—Signor Ibrahim, you muſt not be ſeen here: wait near the garden-gate; your friend Octavio will need your ſervices.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Well, Octavio, take care you make no more miſtakes.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: But we are interrupted: diſſemble your chagrin at what is paſs'd, and fear nothing.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Signor Aldobrand, my errand will apologize for this unſeaſonable viſit.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Rather unſeaſonable, to be ſure; and eſpecially as Viola—

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Sir, I ſpeak to you of Regnalto—I hear he is releaſed from ſlavery.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Releaſed from ſlavery!—Ha!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Why, you ſeem ſurpriz'd: you—

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: My joy overcomes me!—that's all.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: He is ſoon to make his appearance in Florence.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: I ſhould be heartily glad to ſee him— [Aſide— At the devil!] But, pray, how did you hear this news?

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: My lacquey had it this moment from Regnalto's ſervant, Laurence, who is his old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: [Aſide— I'm in a cold chill!] Regnalto's ſervant in Florence!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: In your houſe at this moment!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: In my houſe!—Run, Fabio, and bring him hither immediately!—My old friend's ſervant to be under my roof, and I not know it!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: It rather ſeems as if he meant to conceal himſelf from you.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Egad! that's very true, as you ſay!—Perhaps the dog may have robb'd his maſter; and, when he finds himſelf diſcover'd, he may make off. I had better go and ſee after him myſelf. There are ſo many rogues in the world!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO,
sp.p: Tell me what means—

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Aſk me no queſtions! They believe me dumb; ſtill let them think ſo.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: The charming Viola—

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Accepts the offer which your letter convey'd to her. I will aſſiſt in her elopement; and have a ladder of ropes ready placed at the balcony in the garden.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Tranſport!—And this news of Regnalto—

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Is true!—But here comes Aldobrand.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Then we muſt not be ſeen together.—The garden, at twelve!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Depend on me.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Aye, there's that dog Laurence, ſure enough!—But there's no fear of his running away; he is ſo tipſy, he can hardly ſtand.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: You muſt feel a ſingular ſatisfaction at the approaching return of your old friend Regnalto?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: A very ſingular ſatisfaction, indeed!—I never felt any thing like it before!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Is that Regnalto's ſervant?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: He himſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: There you are miſtaken; for I am not myſelf at preſent.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: And your maſter—

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Like man, like maſter; he is not himſelf, neither. But we ſhall come to ourſelves, both of us, before to-morrow morning!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Where is your maſter? [Aſide— I ſit on pins and needles!]

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: My maſter is at home.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: At home!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: And yet he is not at home—becauſe the people make a ſtranger of him.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Is he in Florence?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: How can I tell? I hardly know where I am myſelf: and if I did, I would not tell you; for, to ſpeak the truth, I have my ſuſpicions of you, my old boy!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Old boy!—Familiar rogue!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Familiar! I am ſure you and I have been very diſtant for theſe nine years paſt.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: A bleſſed ſtate you are in, ſirrah!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Yes, I am married; and that is a bleſſed ſtate you'll never be in.—Do you think, now, that Signora Viola will ever marry ſuch an ugly, decrepit, old——

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Why, you abuſive raſcal!—Out of my ſight!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Signor Octavio, ſhe is a fine girl, and walks in the garden ſometimes!—Love lights her; ſhe does not want the light of the moon.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Eh! what?

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO,
sp.p: That fellow's tongue will diſcover all!

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "What's that you ſaid about the moon?

sp.speaker: "LAURENCE.
sp.p: "That if you were married, you would be very much like the moon.

sp.speaker: "ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: "How!"

sp.speaker: "LAURENCE.
sp.p: "Why, in the courſe of a month, you would certainly have horns!"

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Signor Octavio, you'll pardon my reminding you that it is very late?

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: I underſtand you, Signor: and, as it is near my hour, I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Good night, ſweet Signor!— [Exit OCTAVIO.]—Fabio, I don't know whether I am upon my head or my heels! This Regnalto is certainly in Florence: and then, I don't like what that drunken fellow ſaid to Octavio about Viola's walking in the garden; I fear there is ſome miſchief ſtirring. Tell Guiſeppe and Roberto to get their carbines, and we'll take a walk round the garden; Signor Lucilio, too, ſhall join our company—I am always moſt valiant when I am beſt ſupported!

div.stage: A Ladder of Ropes fix'd to the Balcony.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: This, I think, is the ſpot where Octavio appointed me to ſtand guard.—Alas! if my endeavours for my friend's happineſs are crown'd with no better ſucceſs than thoſe for my own—But I hear voices!
sp.stage: [Retreating to the Back of the Scene.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: I wiſh we could ſee ſome one appear at the window, that we might apprize Viola of her danger.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Happy Viola! to love, and be beloved! while I have laviſh'd my affection on an ingrate; who, perhaps, at this very moment amuſes a happy miſtreſs with the fond tale of my weakneſs!

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Hope, on thee I call,
While thro' thy paths I ſtray;
Where'er my footſteps fall,
Oh! light me on my way.
Tho' loſt in Error's maze,
Still kindly ſoothe my woe;
Nor let Truth's brighter blaze
Shew what I fear to know.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
MONTANO,
sp.p: Pretty advice from a huſband!—'Sdeath! I cannot ſuffer this diſgrace of manhood to exiſt.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Oh, my dear girl—

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: How, a girl!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: How continually has my tongue dwelt on it's deareſt theme—the praiſes of my Montano!

sp.speaker: MONTANO,
sp.p: Montano!—Do I live!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: But it is all over, Roſa!—I will retire from a world which has loſt it's only charm for me; a convent ſhall—

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: This exceſs of joy is too much!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Hark!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: It is the voice of Ibrahim!

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: No, it is a voice with which the gentle Laura ſhould be better acquainted; a voice which, during four cruel years of ſlavery, has never ceaſed to invoke Heaven for her happineſs!

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Oh, Roſa! it is—it is my Montano!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: And ſo ends my firſt chapter of matrimony!—A very excellent mode of getting rid of a wife, without the trouble of a divorce, or the expence of a ſeparate maintenance!—How many poor huſbands would envy me!—But, my dear Madam—and, Sir—you forget that this is a moment as critical to Viola as to yourſelves; and I hear footſteps in the garden.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Let us retire then, my love. From this arbour I can watch whether any one approaches the balcony.

div.stage: Enter LAURENCE, ſtill drunk, with a Bottle in his Hand.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: 'Tis rather a dark night; or elſe I don't ſee clear!

lg.l: Tho' I can't walk quite ſtraight,
And in figures of eight
Still circling my legs do their duty,
You'll always obſerve,
That a regular curve
Is reckon'd the true line of beauty:
Of Orpheus they tell,
(He who fiddled ſo well)
That his notes made hills, rocks, and trees, caper;
So I can, in my way,
When a ſolo I play,
Make them dance full as well as that ſcraper.
Tho' at firſt, on a ſurvey,
Things ſeem topſey-turvey,
When you're us'd to't, they don't look ſo frightful;
Still they move more or leſs,
And good judges confeſs
Moving proſpects are always delightful:
The world's circular motion,
I'm ſure's no falſe notion;
For, tho' ſober I ne'er could believe it,
Truth in wine, boys, is found,
Now I ſee it turns round,
He that's drunk can moſt plainly perceive it.

sp.p: I wonder where my maſter is! As for old Aldobrand, I ſuppoſe he is in bed and aſleep—
sp.stage: Enter ALDOBRAND and FABIO at the Back of the Stage; they approach LAURENCE ſoftly.
sp.p:
But I can't think what's become of my good friend Dummy, as they call him!—Ah, Sir, are you there? I have been looking for you all over the garden.—What! not come to your ſpeech yet?—I'faith, I think you have infected me; for I have not my ſpeech half ſo well as I had a little while ago.—Where is
Signor Octavio?—You don't ſtand ſtill! What makes you ſtagger ſo?—Why don't you anſwer me, Sir? Old Aldobrand can't hear us now.
sp.stage: [ALDOBRAND ſeizes him on one Side, FABIO on the other.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: But he can hear, you hang-dog!—So Dummy can ſpeak, can he?

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: Ah, Signor Aldobrand, is it you?—Upon my ſoul, I did not know you!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND
sp.p: I'll make you know me, you dog, before I have done with you!

sp.speaker: FABIO.
sp.p: Huſh, I hear ſomebody!—Come this way, Sir! [Retiring behind.] To LAURENCE— Sit you down there.

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: I will—and take a nap!

div.stage: VIOLA and ALICE appear at the Window.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: Signor Octavio, where are you?

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: I am frighten'd to death! Signor Octavio—

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK,
sp.p: Bleſs their ſwee't tongues! There is more muſic in a pretty woman's voice than in all the orcheſtras in Italy!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Say who you are?

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: The friend of Octavio; in a word, the dumb ſlave. The ladder of ropes is render'd uſeleſs, for I've ſecur'd the key of the door. But ſomebody approaches!—Deſcend, and I'll be ready to receive you.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Well met, my truſty friends! True, I ſee, to your appointment.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Suppoſe, in caſe of a diſcovery, I were to perſonate Regnalto: his cloaths fit me exactly; and I might by that means further your deſigns.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Not at the expence of my honour; I will not owe my ſucceſs to artifice.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Pſha! a little artifice is often very uſeful: 'tis only retreating from an enemy when he is too powerful for us; and a good pair of heels is ſometimes very ſerviceable—Eh! friend Firelock?

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: A good pair of heels may be as uſeful to a coward as artifice is to a knave: but honeſty as much deſpiſes the aid of the one, as courage diſdains the aſſiſtance of the other!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Viola approaches.

div.stage: Enter VIOLA and ALICE, from a Door under the Balcony.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: My Viola!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: What a tranſition from deſpair to happineſs!—Octavio, I commit myſelf to your honour.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Charming Viola! my affection ſhall prove that your confidence is not miſplaced.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Lights there!—Guiſeppe!—Roberto!—where are you?
Your ſervant, Signor Octavio!— [VIOLA ſhrieks, and ſwoons in REGNALTO's Arms.]—This ſcheme is no better than the other: and you have not got your Algerine friend to back you now.

div.stage: MONTANO comes forward, with LAURA and ROSA.

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: Here I am, Signor Aldobrand, at your ſervice!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: And here am I! You are among friends, you ſee.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Why then, as I am among friends, I ſhall make free!

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: Stand off, if you regard your life!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Thank you for tho hint: I'll take your advice!— [Retreating.] But as for you, my lads, [To the SERVANTS.] fall on!—Seize the lady!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Not while I have an arm to defend her!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Dummy!—Kill him, my boys, in the firſt place!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO.
sp.p: Firſt you have to conquer me, ſlaves!

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Why, Signor Octavio! are you mad?—What right has that fellow to Viola?—Am not I her guardian?

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: And am not I her brother!

sp.speaker: FABIO,
sp.p: It is a pity you ſent for the lights, Sir!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: Sheathe your ſwords; I am maſter here!—Your term is expired, Signor Aldobrand.

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Yes, and I am turn'd out at a moment's warning, I ſee!

sp.speaker: VIOLA.
sp.p: Do I at length embrace my brother!—Kind Heaven, I have no more to aſk!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Except a huſband, Viola! and him I give to you without aſking— [Giving her Hand to OCTAVIO.]—A huſband to whom your brother owes his liberty and life!

sp.speaker: LAURENCE,
sp.p: Hey-day! my old boy, why you are miſtaken again!—You have made a curſed number of blunders this evening!—Rot me, if I believe you are quite ſober!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: And now, my generous friend Ibrahim!—

sp.speaker: MONTANO.
sp.p: No longer Ibrahim, but Montano!—Fortune, who made us companions in adverſity, has compenſated for all by giving you to me as a companion in happier days.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: Signor Montano, I hope you will not forget my firſt huſband!

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Believe me, I ſhall not forget your ſecond as long as I live! I am ſure I found it ſo hard a taſk to perſonate the huſband—

sp.speaker: LAURENCE.
sp.p: That, I ſuppoſe, the next time you get married, you'll perſonate the wife!—Depend upon it, you'll act the part much more naturally.

sp.speaker: ALICE.
sp.p: If ſhe wants a good example, let her copy me, Laurence!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIO,
sp.p: As for you, my noble ſoldier!—

sp.speaker: FIRELOCK.
sp.p: As for me, Signor, I have to thank you for two favours: firſt, for reſtoring to me the greateſt of bleſſings—my liberty! and, ſecondly—for affording me the opportunity of ſhewing my gratitude!

sp.speaker: REGNALTO,
sp.p: Wretch! what have you to ſay in defence of yourſelf?

sp.speaker: ALDOBRAND.
sp.p: Nothing, good Signor Regnalto!—Leaſt ſaid is ſooneſt mended.

sp.speaker: REGNALTO.
sp.p: Repent, then, of your villainy, in ſilence: let us only hear the voice of joy!—We have now the higheſt bleſſing mortals can poſſeſs—that of ſharing the happineſs we create!

lg.l: Away with all care, till to-morrow,
No longer we're deſtin'd to roam;
To-day bid adieu to all ſorrow,
And welcome THE STRANGERS AT HOME.
Away with all care, &c.
No more of Fortune we'll complain,
Since ſhe ſo kind has prov'd at laſt;
Our joys, contraſted with our pain,
Shall brighter ſhine for ſorrows paſt.
On the ſubject now before us,
I would fain my zeal diſplay—
And I, too, would join the Chorus,
If I knew but what to ſay.
My freedom I gladly reſign,
Nor ſhall I for liberty ever repine.
And I from my purpoſe will never depart,
To bind faſter thoſe bonds in which Love holds your heart.
Tho' I've no objection to fighting,
I' faith it is better by half,
With ſuch happy lovers uniting,
To join in the ſong and the laugh!
Believe me, I joy to behold you
All going to be married ſo ſoon—
You know, Ma'am, I often have told you,
A good huſband is Fortune's beſt boon.
When I marry, altho' I won't barter
My own little perſon for pelf,
In wedlock I'll keep up the charter,
And ſtill wear the breeches myſelf.
Away with all care, till to-morrow,
No longer we're deſtin'd to roam;
O chace from our boſoms all ſorrow, [To the Audience.
And welcome THE STRANGERS AT HOME!
